description.narrative: Project title: Strengthening conflict mitigation and prevention capacities in the cross-border areas of Tajikistan
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

- Number of recommendations from ‘TRACTION’ reports that have been implemented by local authorities and community leaders - % of local authorities and community leaders (who have discussed or read the ‘TRACTION’ reports) who indicate that they have used analytical findings and recommendations in their day-to-day work - Number of interventions/ activities/ preventive actions that were implemented by UNDP or other development actors in follow-up of ‘TRACTION’ reports and related research/ trend analysis - Number of documented case studies from cross-border village clusters that demonstrate how mechanisms for dialogue, deliberation, and joint problem-solving helped to reduce local tensions and promoted cross-border cooperation - Number of agreements reached (or project ideas identified) between cross-border communities - % of women taking part in cross-border and intercommunity dialogue - Number of confidence building measures that have been implemented successfully or are in process of being finalized - % of community members that indicate an improvement in cross-border relations - % of community members that have the perception of increased security - Participation of women in planning and formulation of practical measures - Number of UN projects that use data and analytics generated under Output 4 for activities’ planning and implementation - Number of UN staff trained or informed on conflict sensitivity, socio-economic indicators, and opinion survey analysis results - Number of national stakeholders informed on conflict sensitivity, socio-economic indicators, and opinion survey analysis results

comment.narrative: - Community leaders/ authorities in Tajik-Kyrgyz cross-border areas often have a biased view about cross-border conflict dynamics and trends and often contribute to the escalation of local conflicts instead of contributing to de-escalation and peace building - Following the recent violent incidents along the Kyrgyz-Tajik border, spaces for dialogue, deliberation, and joint problem-solving have diminished. - Cross-border linkages, trust and cooperation have decreased as a result of the recent violent conflict in cross-border areas - A limited understanding of the country’s development and security challenges exists due to fragmented and incomplete character of statistical and survey data, shortage of focused analysis, and lack of systematic monitoring

- At least 6 recommendations from ‘TRACTION’ reports have been implemented by local authorities and community leaders - At least 60% of local authorities and community leaders (who have discussed or read the ‘TRACTION’ reports) indicate that they have used analytical findings and recommendations in their day-to-day work - Information from local women on conflict dynamics regularly obtained for the ‘TRACTION’ reports - At least 4 documented case studies from cross-border village clusters that demonstrate how mechanisms for dialogue, deliberation, and joint problem-solving helped to reduce local tensions and promoted cross-border cooperation - At least 8 agreements reached (or project ideas identified) between cross-border communities - At least 40 % of women are taking part in cross-border and intercommunity dialogue - At least 6 confidence building measures have been implemented successfully or in process of being finalized - At least 40% of community members indicate an improvement in cross-border relations (data disaggregated by gender) - At least 50% of community members have the perception of increased security (data disaggregated by gender) - At least 40 % of those who participate in planning and formulation of practical measures are women - At least six UN projects use the generated data and analytics for project planning and implementation - At least 40 UN staff trained or informed on conflict sensitivity, socio-economic indicators, and opinion survey analysis results - At least 60 national stakeholders informed on conflict sensitivity, socio-economic indicators, and opinion survey analysis results

title.narrative: Support to DRR policy in TJK

description.narrative: Project title: Support to the unified and coordinated disaster risk reduction policy and practice in Tajikistan
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

comment.narrative: NDRMS was approved in March 2010. Number of awareness raising events was conducted since, however awareness on the NDRMS as a unified strategic planning document on DRR lacks both within national and international actors. Various DRR initiatives are thus implemented based on ad-hoc and isolated needs assessments and are not always within the national priorities defined in NDRMS. All preparatory work for launch of the National Platform for DRR was done in 2011 and the Platform is expected to be officially established in 2012. First year of its functioning will be crucial to prove the value added and ensure sustainable functioning of the Platform without external support
• Shelter and non-food emergency supplies sufficient to cover the needs of 1000 households are ready to be dispatched within 24 hours.

description.narrative: Project title: Improved information management in emergencies
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

comment.narrative: 1. Emergency services such as Fire Brigades, Police, Search and Rescue teams, Ambulance and others are organized within different institutions and coordinated dispatch and operation on the site is ineffective. The Crisis management Center of CoES (established with the support of Japanese government in 2011), is a well-equipped premises. However, each of the main emergency services has their operations centers and to get the teams to emergency site the requester needs to go through several parallel communications. This leads to inefficient and often time consuming emergency response. Cross communication with other emergency services within the country is not widely practiced and there is need to a unified telecom system. 2. The CoES telecommunication “111” Center operates 24/7 and the call operators are responsible for incoming calls as well as forwarding the call to other relevant departments of emergency services. These officers are able to respond to incoming calls and forward and/or collect and record the required information. However, they require training on e.g. negotiations in emergencies, psychological support to the caller and redirection of calls to other emergency services. Important capacity building needs also should also include trainings on crisis management/incident command/information management and telecommuting services. In order to establish a unified telecom system an additional IT infrastructure connecting all emergency services into one coordination hub is also of vital importance.

1. One study tour conducted. 2. MOU and SoPs approved. 3. One training for IT staff of emergency service conducted. 4. One training conducted and capacity of emergency services on data collection, processing and transfer built. 5. Interagency simulation exercise conducted. 6. At least two public outreach campaigns conducted. 7. At least one training on psychosocial help and code of conduct conducted.

description.narrative: Project title: Improved Policy Making Mechanisms for Disaster Risk Reduction Initiatives in Tajikistan
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1.1 Annual Work Plan of the National Platform prepared and followed-up. 1.2 # of the quarterly meetings of the National Platform. 1.3 # of roundtables, trainings and workshops for NP working groups. 1.4 Agreed and approved document outlining the roles and responsibilities of each National Platform stakeholder. 1.5 # and type of strategic development planning documents with consideration of DRR. 1.6 UN Official Recognition of Tajikistan National Platform. 2.1 Approved SoPs to be applied by all NDRMS stakeholders for reporting on its implementation. 2.2 2013 Annual report on NDRMS implementation prepared and followed-up. 2.3 # of round tables and trainings/presentations on implementation of DNRMS action plans; 2.4 NDRMS Integrated Risk Management Framework document. 2.5 National Platform Memo/note outlining the inputs of Tajikistan for post HFA document and priority directions for post NDRMS period. 3.1 # of REACT meetings; 3.2 # of REACT Thematic Working group meetings. 3.3 Situations reports, damage and needs assessment reports, Humanitarian Appeals following the disasters. 3.4 Updated REACT Statement of Common Understanding, Damage and Needs Assessment tools and other REACT tools. 3.5 MoU (s) on handover of Secretariat functions to other agencies.

comment.narrative: 1. Establishment of National Platform for DRR has been approved in March of 2012 and it has been meeting regularly since then. However, as it was expected, activities of the National Platform were rather formal and had limited effectiveness, indicating that there is still as need in: strengthening the capacities of the NP Secretariat, improvement the knowledge on overall DRR cycle of all actors, strong leadership and involvement of the high level participants and etc. Ensuring mentioned factors will enable National Platform to be a driving force to foster the integration of DRR into national and local development planning. 2. One of the primary responsibilities of the newly established National Platform is the coordination and monitoring of the implementation of the NDRMS. Taking into account, that at the moment of the NDRMS approval (2010), National Platform was not formally established, given responsibility was designated to CoES by the Government of Tajikistan. CoES, on its turn has managed (UNDP supported) to develop basic M&E system on implementation of the NDRMS, which included the set of results, indicators and etc. Nonetheless, a higher level of influence and more centralized role is required for CoES to ensure appropriate quality monitoring and especially to ensure effective coordination. 3. REACT is a reputable, well-known and well-established partnership of state and non-governmental actors in the field of DRR in general. However, at larger extent REACT is considered to be more operational forum, mainly focusing on supporting the state in implementation of the existing DRR/M policies. With the establishment of the National Platform there is a need to ensure strong and permanent information flow and communication among above mentioned structures. This will enable National Platform to take an account of tools, experience and knowledge of REACT while developing new DRR strategies/policies and will enable REACT (dominated by non-state actors) to participate

1. At least two capacity building activities implemented for the members of the National Platform and Expert Group. 2. At least one NP and four Expert group meetings conducted. 3. At least one joint DCC WG and NP meeting conducted. 4. Participation of Tajik delegation in Third World Conference on DRR ensured. 5. At least one round table on monitoring of NDRMS implementation conducted. 6. At least one consultation on national priorities for post-HFA and post-NDRMS conducted. 7. Unified warning and response system for emergency situations established. 8. At least one regular REACT meeting conducted. 9. Lessons learned workshop conducted and responsible parties for regional REACT Secretariat identified. 10. At least two on-job trainings conducted for Regional REACT Secretariat. 11. Exchange visit to Sughd conducted and Regional REACTs reactivated. 12. NP website developed and launched.

description.narrative: Project title: Sustained development progress through effective identification, monitoring and reduction of the existing disaster risks at all levels in Tajikistan
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

comment.narrative: 1. NDRMS endorsed in 2010, NP for DRR established in 2012. REACT exists as a humanitarian coordination platform. Challenges in coordinated reporting on NDRMPS implementation hamper transparency and mutual accountability between state and non-state actors. Development planning (incl. commercial investments) marginally includes DRR. Development planning at local level is formal, unfunded and largely not linked to needs (supply driven). 2. Recovery experiences reviews, Recovery Framework for REACT developed in 2011, respective trainings on recovery and DRR provide to REACT and UNDP staff. 3. Need for similar document for government actors agreed with NP for DRR. Seismic risk assessment of 3 hospitals conducted in 2012. Adequacy of the Methodology was not reviewed/reconfirmed. UNDP projects reviewed and DRR integration Action Plan and DRR Certification Methodology developed. 4. National RA methodology exists, MEWS established within MEDT. Application of the RA methodology and maintenance of the quality of the MEWS output info is a challenge.

1. Report on implementation of LSIS for 2013-2015 indicates implementation of DRR by the stakeholders. 2. One Study tour for NP members conducted. 3. At least two DDPs developed. 4. At least 8 DRR project at district level implemented. 5. One UNDP project/programme received DRR certification. 6. At least 1 Recovery project implemented. 7. Capacity of NP Secretariat improved, at least two NP meetings conducted. 8. National Recovery guide endorsed by Government/NP. 9. Recovery coordination ensured. 10. Risk assessment conducted in at least three districts conducted. 11. At least twelve national and twelve regional MEWSA reports produced. 12. RMEWS expanded into other regions. 13. At least two hazards mapped and data available for national and international stakeholders.

description.narrative: Flood Recovery to Resilience Programme, Tajikistan
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

• Affected households provided with cows and poultry. • Vaccination and regular examination of distributed animals conducted. • Seeds and fertilizer for household garden production distributed. • Tools and fencing for household gardens distributed. • Sustainable water supply system constructed. • Trainings for existing Water User Association (WUA) on water management provided. • Equipment for operation and management of the water system provided. • Site design for reallocation site developed • Houses for most affected households constructed. • Health center in Chubek jamoat repaired. • Health center for relocated population at new settlement constructed. • Flood and mudflow assessment conducted involving international and local expertise. • Hazard management plan developed for Sarichashma watershed. • Awareness raising and consultation activities conducted. • Hazard warning system established. • Technical support on weather forecast provided. • Weather data collection equipment installed. • Trainings on weather data collection and analysis conducted. • Conduction of risk and hazard assessments. • Development of jamoat resilience plan.

comment.narrative:
On 12-13 April 2014, due to heavy rains and hailstorm flash floods and mudslides hit several districts of Kulyab zone, south east of Khatlon Province. Namely Hamadoni, Kulyab, Muminobod, Shuroobod and Vose districts were affected. Severely affected areas include Sarichashma Jamoat of Shuroobod district, Tugarak Jamoat of Vose district and Balkhobi Jamoat of Muminobod district. Fifteen people fell victim to the disaster during the first two days. Significant damages have been observed in more than 487 households, livelihoods and local infrastructure, including health and education facilities. Severely affected communities include Sarichashma jamoat of Shuroobod district, where in addition to the 104 families affected, more than 500 head of the cattle has been killed. The affected population of more than 780 people has been relocated to tent camp. Under current component the livelihood support activities are envisaged to restore normal livelihood of those affected.
The current setback to the immediate implementation of the relocation plan is that the Bobo Nosirov site lacks a sustainable water supply. While an existing section of Bobo Nosirov (settled some decades ago) has access to piped water, assessments indicate that the supply is currently insufficient for the additional relocated families. The relocation cannot take place if the families to be moved do not have access to water, making a water supply system a prerequisite for moving families to a safer location. It is foreseen to establish a sustainable water supply for the Bobo Nosirov relocation site. This will involve extension of the existing spring source to handle increased demand through spring development, pumps, pipes, storage facilities and a reticulation system with household meters. The water system will be run through an existing water user association (WUA), with operating costs covered through fees collected based on household water use meters. The Government has already established a site plan

1. One hundred households benefited from cow distribution. 2. One hundred households benefited from poultry distribution. 3. All distributed domestic animals vaccinated and passed regular examination. 4. Seeds, fertilizer, tools and fencing distributed for household garden production. 5. Sustainable water supply system reconstructed. 6. At least one trainings conducted on water management. 7. Appropriate equipment for operation and management of the water system headed over to WUA. 8. At least 15 houses built for the most affected households 9. Site design available for further use by local authorities. 10. One Health center in Chubek Jamoat repaired. 11. One Health center in Bobo Nosirov location constructed. 12. Flood and mudflow assessment report available for further use 13. Hazard management plan developed. 14. (number) of awareness raising and consultation activities conducted. 15. Hazard warning system established and well-functioning. 16. Local authorities have appropriate knowledge on weather forecast. 17. Equipment for weather data collection available 18. Improved capacity of local stakeholders on weather data collection and analysis. 19. Assessments conducted, risk and hazards are identified. 20. Jamoat Resilience plan developed.

There is less linkage between the victim assistance policy and development concept of supporting PwDs. 3.5. description.narrative: Adapted and enhanced legislative and regulatory framework for small-scale hydropower development in the country.
Adopted regulation operationalizing RES Law

comment.narrative: No regulations in support of RES Law
Rules and regulations adopted by end of Year 1

The legislative and regulatory frameworks for small scale hydropower development created in the previous years with the project’s support, the law on Renewable Energy Sources and the law on Energy efficiency and energy saving, have led the Government to adoption of strategic documents in favor of renewable energy development. As such the national programme for small hydropower plants construction was revised, and the national strategy for the development of renewable energy sources and energy efficiency is being developed. The revised national programme that will cover the period of 2015-2020 will include the small hydro, solar and wind energy sources, and during the reporting period the programme is being adopted.
Adopted sub-laws to the law on Renewable Energy Sources also regulate the conditions for the solar and wind energy sources, although the project does not directly aim at development of these sources. Nevertheless, the latest developments of renewables in the country suggest that combined application of renewable sources along with small hydropower would better address the issues with the lack of energy in the rural communities. The project has therefore been effective in communicating this message to the government, which was endorsed.

description.narrative: Enhanced technical and planning know-how and developed market chain for SHP in Tajikistan
% of the total SHP installed cost provided by locally made goods and services

comment.narrative: 50% by the end of Year 4

In line with the developed regulations for SHP development, the capacities to produce, maintain and operate SHPPs were created through the transfer of technology to beneficiary companies, Energoremont and Korgohi Mashinasozi, and through educating students at the Technical universities in Dushanbe and Kurgantyube. The local manufacturers’ supported by the project have produced, tested and installed portable turbines, where the share of locally produced goods and services is estimated at over 50%. The companies are now engaged in the production and installation of electromechanical equipment for additional 4 SHPPs.
The human capacity of the technicians and experts in SHPP development and management is being built through the project. Annually, a total of 100 students from the technical universities are taking SHPP courses based on the modules developed with the project’s support.. To date 300 students have been reported to have received these courses at the Tajik Technical University and Kurgantyube Energy Institute.

description.narrative: Improved confidence on the technical and economic viability of integrated SHP-based rural development model
No. of SHP demos/pilots incorporating aspects of productive uses and livelihood support for host communities

comment.narrative: At least 5 community-owned SHP projects operate on a sustainable basis and at least 5 additional are under construction by the end of Year 4

Total of 3 community-owned SHPPs (Nurofar, Yazghulam and Sorvo) are operating on sustainable basis and 4 more are under construction. Sustainability of the constructed SHPPs is ensured through the introduced management mechanisms, fee collection methods, capacity building of the operators through trainings and provision of basic equipment. Additionally, SHPP Nurofar sells excess electricity to the local businesses (fuel station, dairy shop and the plastic windows production workshop) during the summer time based on contractual agreement. This measure allows the SHPP to operate on sustainable basis, as well as allowing the local businesses to have savings from the electricity bills. The national tariff for businesses is 33 dirams per kW (0.05 USD) whereas the SHPP offers a trade off electricity for 25 dirams per kW (0.038 USD).

description.narrative: National Scaling-up Programme of Renewable Energy-based Integrated Rural Development
Adopted and financed National Scaling-up Program

comment.narrative: N/a
Adopted and financed National Scaling-up Program by the end of Year 4

Through continuous dialogue and political advice rendered to the government counterparts by the project and the international community operating in the energy sector, the Government has and is adopting a number of strategies in the energy sector, one of which is the National Strategy for Renewable Energy and corresponding action plans and national programmes. The programme and the strategies aim at scaling-up renewable energy based integrated rural development.
For instance, the government has already provided direct investments for SHP construction. In 2012 -2014 the amount invested by the Government cumulatively constituted USD 4.4 mln for 5 SHPPs with a total capacity of 1,967 kW. This investment has resulted in covering 1,500 households, schools, hospitals, as well as the business facilities and created employment for 200 people in remote rural areas of the country.

description.narrative: Formulated, approved and enforced implementing rules and regulations (IRRs) of the new Law for RES that will facilitate actions geared towards the enhancement of the market environment for SHP

Simplified procedures and principles for the licensing and construction of SHP facilities
National RE/EE Fund

comment.narrative:
RES Law includes a number of provisions to facilitate investment in grid-connected RE projects, but they are not operationalized
National RE/EE Fund

Procedures adopted and enforced by end of Year 1
National RE/EE Fund set-up and is operational by end of Year 2

A permanent inter-institutional working group for the implementation of the law "on energy saving and energy efficiency" and elaboration of proposals to implement the law has been established. Inter-institutional working group has 3 sub-groups responsible for: (i) issues related to establishment of Trust Fund for RES and EE; (ii) development of the National Strategy on RES and National energy saving program; and (iii) development of legal acts. The group is chaired by the Ministry of energy and water resources.
The charter of the Trust Fund has been revised to best meet the current developments in the renewable energy sector and was endorsed by 5 ministries except for the Ministry of Finance. The financial part of the trust fund still remains unresolved due to the lack of financial commitments from the main international institutions operating in the country that were considered as the primary source of funds along with the national contributions. It has to be mentioned however that the share of the national contribution remains unknown and requires further discussions.

description.narrative: Central and local government institutions with enhanced capacities to develop and coordinate SHP projects.
# staff members from relevant central and local government institutions trained in developing and coordinating SHP projects

comment.narrative: 30 staff members trained by the end of Year 2

In addition to the trainings carried out by the project for the Government representatives during the previous reporting year, the capacity assessment of the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources staff was conducted. It has been revealed that there is a significant gap in the planning of RES projects, especially in the financial and economic analysis of the SHPP projects, which creates a barrier for adequately managing and coordinating resources expanded for the construction of SHPPs. In this regard, the project in cooperation with EU Sustainable Energy Programme for Central Asia (CASEP), and direct involvement of the project’s Chief Technical Adviser, organized 3-days trainings on “Creating and managing the SHPP cadastre”, “Business game: Practical development of RES projects” and “Financial and economic analysis of SHPP projects” which have helped to increase the capacity of 45 staff of the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources and Barki Tojik (the national electricity utility company).

description.narrative: Local workshops and manufacturers with enhanced capacities to install, construct, manufacture and repair SHP system equipment and components
Technology transfer and capacity development plan prepared for selected local manufacturers

comment.narrative: 2 technology transfer and capacity development plan prepared by the end of Year 1

The capacities of the local manufacturers (Energoremont and Korgohi Mashinasozi) to design, manufacture, construct, install and repair the SHP systems are further enhanced. The local manufacturers have received additional sets of needed equipment for the production of the SHPPs that include electronic and mechanical tools and equipment.
Under the supervision and direct coaching of the technology transfer deliverer, the local manufacturers have mastered the production of the portable turbines (2 x 15 kW) that were installed and commissioned on a pilot basis. Based on this experience, the manufacturers have been prepared for the manufacturing, construction, installation and repair of larger electromechanical equipment for SHPPs. Both manufacturers are now able to produce turbines and set into operation SHPPs of ranging capacities from 1 kW to 1,000 kW.

description.narrative: Vocational training program for technicians involved in SHP design/construction and O&M
# of technicians annually undertaking vocational training on SHP

comment.narrative: 20 technicians annually undertaking vocational training on SHP starting from Year 2

The project has signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Tajik-Technical University to provide vocational trainings to technicians involved in SHP production. Based on the signed MoU the project has helped the university in developing the vocational training modules and provided IT equipment (a laptop, overhead projector and a screen). In August 2014, 3-day vocational trainings for 18 technicians from Vahdat district and 7 representatives of the Ministries of Energy of Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan were held. The practical trainings were carried out on the facilities of Energoremont and Korgohi Mashinasozi with which the University has agreements..
In September 2014, the OSCE office in Dushanbe has requested the services of the University to educate 15 technicians in Rasht valley.

description.narrative: Local manufacturers capable of producing combined electric and biomass-fired heating and cooking devices for rural households
# of local craft workshops capable of manufacturing and assemblage of simple, efficient and low-cost electric heating and cooking devices

comment.narrative: At least 1 local craft workshops by the end of Year 3

A Project study on the viability of producing the combined electrical and biomass fired heating and cooking device indicates that production of the devices locally will not be sustained: a) Local power supplies of 1 kW will not be sufficient to operate the device reducing its demand; and b) limited demand for these devices is expected due to the flooding of less expensive Chinese goods. The target is to be cancelled based on the recommendations of the Mid-Term Review.

description.narrative: Technical studies, political commitments and institutional framework secured for pilot SHP projects

Feasibility studies

comment.narrative: FS for 2 sites by end of Year 1, 3 sites - by end of Year 2, 5 sites - by end of Year 3. IDDP for 2 districts by end of Year 2, 3 districts - by end of Year 3, At least 5 further SHP projects identified and construction started (without direct project support)

The feasibility studies have been completed in the previous reporting period.
The IDDPs for 5 districts have been reviewed and updated accordingly.
5 SHPPs with a total capacity of 1,967 kW was constructed by the Government. Additionally, OSCE has supported the construction of 2 micro SHPPs (10 kW each) in Rasht Valley. IFC has signed an agreement with the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources for the construction of 18 MW hydropower plant in Zervashan valley. The Japan Government funded “Livelihoods Improvement in Tajikistan-Afghanistan Cross border Areas” (LITACA) project implemented by UNDP finances construction of 2 SHPPs in Shurabad and Jilikul districts. The electromechanical equipment for these two SHPPs (175 kW and 100 kW) will be produced by the local manufacturers supported by the project.

description.narrative: Pilot SHP operations sustained

Number of PPAs signed for purchase of power from pilot SHP plants by EOP
Number of local business supported in pilot localities

comment.narrative: At least 2 by the end of Year and 5 by the end of Year 4

The operation of the two commissioned pilot SHPPs in Burunov and Yazghulom are sustained by regular monitoring and provided technical support to the operators responsible for the operation-maintenance and management of the plants. The operators of these plants have been educated through the vocational trainings and have been supplied with the maintenance tools and equipment. The SHPP in Yazghulam that provides electricity to the border outpost on the Tajik-Afghan border is sustained by the technicians serving in the border post. The plant in Burunov on the other hand provides electricity to a number of clients including the households and the social and economic facilities, and has been connected to the national grid. Both SHPPs are operating in a sustainable manner.

description.narrative: Project title: Initial Implementation of Accelerated HCFC Phase Out in the CEIT Region
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: 1. No formal HCFC strategy is adopted and enforced through regulatory measures 2. Inter-agency coordination to address HCFC phase-out is limited 3. No updated HCFC and HCFC equipment import quota and use system is in place 4. Low level of awareness related to HCFC phase-out across stakeholders and general public 5. No current information products and programs; 6. Key Government stakeholders have limited awareness of HCFC phase-out issue, challenges to address it and skills/tools to enforce HCFC control measures in practice 7. Limited active educational efforts or tools are available 8. Illegal trade in ODS continues unregistered and unnoticed 9. Lack of portable HCFC analytical equipment and modern skills to control illegal imports 10. General absence of basic servicing tools to strengthen HCFC re-use system 11. Alternative technologies are not commonly used for retrofit of existing systems and are not field tested to facilitate practical introduction 12. Refrigerated equipment in poor condition continues to be serviced with the use of HCFCs and maintained by the companies in these sectors 13. No or minimal investment is taking place to retrofit or replace HCFC equipment with alternative refrigerant systems 14. No or minimal information is available on opportunities to reduce dependence to HCFC 15. Limited proliferation of low GWP alternatives (NH3, CO2 double stage, HCs etc) to HCFCs in refrigerated equipment; 16. Safety standards for new low GWP alternatives do not exist 17. Generally low awareness on new alternative technologies in the servicing sector and benefits in energy savings (co-benefits for economic operations as well as for climate change) 18. Lack of experience with, knowledge of and skills to assemble, install, operate and maintain HCFC-free commercial/industrial equipment using non-ODS/low-zero GWP technologies (NH3, CO2 double stage, HCs etc) 19. Low readiness for/acceptance of new technologies by end-users 20. No active network to facilitate reuse

description.narrative: Project title: Tajikistan Water Supply and Sanitation Project (TajWSS) (phase II)
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1.1. By end of 2014 sanitation plan is discussed and endorsed by the Network 1.2. By Jan. 2015 changes to the sanitation and water quality policies, adopted by the IMCC 1.3. By end of 2015 Law on Water Users Associations revised to clarify their mandate in drinking water supply and sanitation systems operation and management 1.4. By Jan. 2015 relevant stakeholders have increased expertise in advocating on gender and WS&S issues
2.1 Increase in willingness to pay and increased tariff collection rates to 65% by Y2 and 90% by Y4 2.2. The new district will adopt the institutional changes implemented during Phase 1 2.3. Hukumat commits at least 10% investment cost in the selected district 2.4. At least 2 models for disseminating gender knowledge and awareness tested and replicated in target district by Y4
3.1. In 3 villages at least 50% reduction in time to collect water for women and children 3.2. In 3 villages at least a 20% reduction in the monthly rates of diarrhoea by the Y4 3.3. In 3 schools in the targeted villages at least a 10% reduction in school absenteeism (disaggregated by sex)
Project title: Support to development of the UNDP Programme on Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRM) based water sector development and Transboundary Water Cooperation
Environment - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative:
Water sector in Tajikistan lacks conformity with IWRM-based management principles.
The legal and institutional framework lack compliance with IWRM principles; water institutions lack capacity to comply with IWRM principles to water management; poor mechanisms to ensure water integrity in pilot basins.
Transboundary water resources management at global and regional level lack conformity with internationally agreed water-related goals, including sustainable development goals, and require greater cooperation and interaction between beneficiary states.

description.narrative: Project title: Support to effective regulatory framework and private sector involvement for drinking water supply and sanitation sector in Tajikistan
Environment - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative:
Lack of clear roles amongst duty bearers in policy, regulation and management of drinking water supply and sanitation sector
Water service providers have poor contact with consumers at the ground, lack knowledge and practice on good governance mechanisms; and consumers lack knowledge and practice to demand transparent and accountable service delivery

comment.narrative: • Absence of textbook on HD for students is a barrier in study process • Absence of electronic source of HD materials • Lack of integrated approach in assessment of MDG achieving in the context of HD • Lack of understanding HD concept among stakeholders; • Absence of stakeholders’ awareness on the undertaken actions to follow up to NHDRs’ recommendations; • Weak capacity of national experts to develop NHDRs • Data deficit for NHDR development related to specific thematic related areas at local level • Lack of researches on estimation of socio-economic capacity in the context of Human Development at local (district/city) level to be used for Human Development mainstreaming into specific development plans, programme strategies and project interventions at local level .

1. Number of Human Development manuals published for university students 3. National Human Development report developed and published 4. Number of participatory consultations are conducted to discuss the NHDR development to ensure that the results of the report are accepted by relevant stakeholders. 5. Availability of the matrix of actions to follow up to NHDR's recommendations. 6 Multidisciplinary team of experts is trained on mainstreaming HD principals into Development strategies. and policies.

1. Two Human Development focused Courses of Lectures, with financial support from UNDP / MHDT Project - ‘Socio-economic prognostication’ with RTSU and ‘Comparative management’ with TUT were published and disseminated among university students learning Human Development Course in 8 Institutes of Higher Education. 3. NHDR 2014 “Tajikistan: access to resources for the Human Development” was published (150copies in English, 150 copies in Tajik, 100 copies in Russian and an additional 200 CDs with NHDR in three languages) and uploaded in the UNDP site. 4.Official ceremony of Launch of NHDR 2014 “Tajikistan: access to resources for the Human Development” was conducted on 8-th of April 2015 for 100 representatives of Government institutions, National and international partners, Embassies. 4. Republican theoretical and practical conference ‘Mainstreaming of Human Development Concept in Tajikistan and evaluation of its results’ took place on 30-th of April 2015 in the Tajik National University with financial and technical support of UNDP/MHDT project . 4.International symposium: ‘Tajikistan-2030: on the way to Sustainable Human Development’ was conducted by Strategic Research Centre with technical and financial support of UNDP /MHDT project. It took placeon 12-th November 2015 Materials of the conference were published. 5. Recommendations on elaboration and implementation of Country Development Strategies in the context of Sustainable Human Development, were developed and published in Tajik and Russian and delivered to the Government Working Group, established for development NDS-2030 and MDPT for 2016-2020, and the Ministry of Economic Development and Trade for further dissemination to the national, regional and local government bodies. 6. title.narrative: Strengthening Capacity for an Environmental Information

description.narrative: Strengthening Capacity for an Environmental Information Management and Monitoring System in Tajikistan

title.narrative: Project Document "Strengthening capacity for an environmental information management and monitoring system in Tajikistan"

description.narrative: Project title: Strengthening capacity for an environmental information management and monitoring system in Tajikistan
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. Adequate national budget allocation to environmental monitoring 2. Capacity development monitoring scorecard rating 3. Quality of environmental monitoring reports and communications to measure implementation progress of the Rio Conventions in Tajikistan 4. Adequate legislation and policies for environmental information management and monitoring developed, detailing the institutional set-up, mandates of institutions and coordination and reporting mechanisms 5. The environmental monitoring institutional set-up and capacities are adequate for monitoring the state of the environment and responding to international obligations of Tajikistan 6. The in-service training programme for public servants include course(s) covering environmental information management and monitoring systems 7. Number of public servants trained by taking the course(s) on environmental information and monitoring systems 8. Adequate environmental indicators approved and monitored 9. Adequate national standards, norms, procedures for monitoring these environmental indicators are officially in place 10. Examples of environmental monitoring information being used in national reports and communications 11. Up-to-date environmental information readily available to decision makers 12. Examples of development plans, policies and strategies that include global environmental indicators 13. Examples of increased mobilization of government resources to monitor the environment

comment.narrative:  A government budget of $112,000 in 2014 was allocated to environmental monitoring. Capacity for: • Engagement: 3 of 9 • Generate, access and use information and knowledge: 6 of 12 • Policy and legislation development: 4 of 9 • Management and implementation: 3 of 6 • Monitor and evaluate: 2 of 6  (total score: 18/42)  Current reports are produced with limited data, weak analysis and weak trend analysis  Existing reports do not respond to national and international requirements  The current legislation contained in the relevant Laws and policies are not comprehensive enough for the implementation of an adequate national environmental monitoring system  Various institutions are currently mandated to monitor some environmental elements with no national coordination, duplication of some functions and limited capacities  The current in-service training programme for public administrators does not include any course on environmental information management and monitoring system  The existing set of environmental indicators is not comprehensive and does not respond to the national and international information requirements  There is no unified set of standards, norms and procedures to collect data, conduct observations and make sampling  Limited use of environmental monitoring information in national reports and communications  Limited availability of environmental monitoring information; often due to documents being “classified” or “restricted”.  Limited integration of environmental indicators and monitoring information into development plans, policies and strategies  Limited allocation of government resources to environmental monitoring

description.narrative: Border Management in Northern Afghanistan II
Defence - policy, planning and administration

Output 1: - Number of ABP officers and staff trained. - Number of Border Police Units benefiting from the presence and capacity building activities of Training and Mentoring Team (s). - Number of ABP units benefiting from BOMNAF developed training materials. - Number of Border management infrastructure built, furnished and equipped. - BOMNAF provided facilities and equipment are well maintained and supported - Number of officers stationed at BOMNAF constructed facilities received specialized equipment.
Output 2: - Development of an implementation plan on interagency and cross‐border cooperation - Number of field events facilitated and supported. - Number of joint meetings and high level seminars supported between border officials from Afghanistan with their counterpart from Central Asia.
Output 3: - Creation and functionality of the Regional Technical Working Group - Number of joint activities between borderland communities and ABP - Number of joint cross‐border workshops, symposia at Border Crossing Points - Number of joint patrolling activities - Adopted conference declaration - Number of regional development and cross‐border initiatives supported.

comment.narrative: - Weak capacity and efficiency of ABP on Border Management on Afghanistan’s Northern border. - Weak inter‐agency and cross‐border communication, cooperation, and coordination between Afghanistan and Central Asia - Weak collaboration between border management agencies with the borderland residents.
